summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend by mocking the player's brief seven-minute appearance for Tottenham against Burnley on Twitter. This follows a previous dispute where Merson had criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, a comment he retracted after Townsend scored a great equalizer for England against Italy. Townsend had previously responded to the initial criticism on social media after his goal. Despite Merson having admitted he was wrong and the bad feeling seeming to have passed, he made another dig at Townsend following the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to sign FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto. If the transfer is completed, Muto will immediately be sent on loan to Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem for the next season. FC Tokyo's president confirmed the bid and stated that Chelsea's interest is not related to their recent £200 million sponsorship deal with the Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who has 11 international caps for Japan, has not yet decided on the move but called the offer an honor. A £4 million fee has been suggested for the player, who scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for his club.

A large-scale Finnish study published in Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, with repeated prescriptions before age two further increasing the odds. The research, which analyzed over 12,000 children, suggests antibiotics may contribute to weight gain by killing gut bugs that normally consume some food, thereby making more calories available and potentially increasing appetite. While not proving causation, the authors warn this could be a factor in the childhood obesity epidemic and highlight the importance of judicious antibiotic use, noting boys were particularly prone to this effect.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, an incident witnessed by hundreds of tourists and captured on video by holidaymaker David Meadwell. The guard lost his footing, dropped his rifle, and knocked his bearskin hat, but quickly scrambled to his feet as his colleagues continued marching. It is thought his metal-soled boots caused the slip on the manhole cover. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the event.

The A&E Networks, including A&E, Lifetime, and History, are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots" for a 2016 simulcast. This new version, co-executive produced by LeVar Burton from the original, will draw more from Alex Haley's novel and consult scholars for authenticity. The remake aims to introduce the powerful saga of Kunta Kinte and his descendants to a new generation of viewers, who have a different historical context including the Obama presidency and recent racial unrest.

Police are investigating claims by former royal footman Christopher Lawler that in 1978, aides at Clarence House attempted to force him into an orgy by pinning him to a chair and groping him on his first day of work. He reported the incident that day but was allegedly met with an angry response and left the job. After inquiries into historical VIP child sex abuse began last year, Lawler contacted the palace again; his complaints were ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide was interviewed and denied involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with any police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced Melissa's pregnancy by creating a parody rap video set to the theme song of "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." Their video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, details their life in Happy Valley and their journey to conceive in just two months. The clip, filmed in five takes, ends with them sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. They created the video to share the news with distant loved ones and were surprised by its viral success. Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek.

A gray jacket and skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold at auction for $137,000. The dress, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray color, was worn in several key scenes and was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film sold by Heritage Auctions. The collection belonged to James Tumblin, who originally acquired the dress for $20 in the 1960s to save it from being discarded. Other notable items sold included a hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable for $55,000, and a bonnet for $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell approximately 10-12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over a railing. The child was rescued by his parents and suffered only minor injuries, as the cheetahs did not approach him. Following the incident, the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family based on eyewitness accounts, and the exhibit was closed.

A non-operational speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which had been deactivated for over two years along with 300 other outdated devices in the West Midlands, was found repositioned to point directly at a house. Birmingham City Council, aware of the situation, stated the fixed cameras were decommissioned in 2013 due to obsolete technology and that a pilot for new digital cameras is in development. An engineer will visit the site to potentially remove the camera, which will not be part of the new pilot program.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for the Jamaican team at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt stated he is fit, healthy, and ready to run, and he looks forward to upholding Jamaica's successful relay tradition and making his country proud. The JAAA confirmed his availability, and the full team list will be announced shortly.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at the London Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km is held by Australian Rohan Dennis. Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and Tour de France winner, is ending his road career to return to track cycling, with this attempt being part of his preparation for the 2016 Rio Olympics where he is targeting an eighth Olympic medal. Tickets for the event will go on sale on April 19.

Serena Williams described her difficult three-set Fed Cup singles victory over Sara Errani as an "eye-opener," revealing she is not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought and must adjust her hard-court style of play. Despite her win, the U.S. team lost the tie 3-2 to Italy after Williams and Alison Riske were defeated in the decisive doubles rubber, resulting in the U.S. being relegated to World Group II.

River Plate are interested in signing Manchester United's Radamel Falcao, with the club's vice president stating they "dream of" his return and that "the doors are open." Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club for eight years and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances, has struggled on loan at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals. It is uncertain if United will keep him or if he will return to his parent club, Monaco.

In 2015, X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson became the official face of the Batiste dry shampoo brand for its 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand endorsement. The international campaign included images of her with various hairstyles against a city background and a TV ad featuring her single "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement for the partnership, stating she regularly uses the product, and her management noted the natural synergy between the international artist and the globally used brand.

In Kenosha, Wisconsin, a billboard funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, featuring Officer Pablo Torres and thanking the community, has caused shock and distress to the family and friends of Aaron Siler, whom Torres fatally shot on March 14. Siler was killed after arming himself during a confrontation following a pursuit; he was wanted on a felony warrant. The family and their friend called the billboard disrespectful and have asked for its removal, while the police association stated it was only intended to thank the community for its support during a difficult time. This shooting occurred ten days after Torres shot and wounded another armed individual, an incident that was investigated and deemed justified. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, with Iranian forces killing three militants. The militants, who crossed from Pakistan according to Iranian officials, were claimed by the group Jaish al Adl, a Sunni Muslim group that targets Shiites and opposes Iranian influence. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not controlling these militants, who have been responsible for previous attacks. Pakistan condemned the attack, stated its security agencies are investigating, and promised to apprehend the militants if they entered its territory.

Japanese Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated in parliament that the country's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO, confirming that scrambled jets have only ever found earthly objects like birds. This was in response to a question from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler who claims to have seen a UFO himself. The discussion echoes a 2007 instance where a former defense minister considered the legal ramifications of defending against an alien invasion.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts requiring dozens of stitches after a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport broke. He was standing on the rim because he was worried about cleanliness when the porcelain toilet tipped over and shattered. He called his companions for help instead of shouting and was later taken to the hospital. While he initially confessed to squatting, he later told police he was sitting, possibly to avoid compensation, though authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded the public that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested and faces multiple charges including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. An investigation revealed Rebbie had sexually abused the girl from ages 9 to 13 and had filmed her and other juveniles showering and using the bathroom over a four-year period, with 41 videos found uploaded to his computer. Rebbie admitted to purchasing the camera specifically to record the victim. He is being held on $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing scheduled for May 1.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's series of images, part of a book roughly titled "Daughter and Salary Man," features daughters standing po-faced next to their fathers, who are leaping into the air in energetic, sometimes pained, poses. The fathers are dressed in sharp suits, representing salarymen expressing a fun side, while the daughters wear casual clothing. The pairs are photographed in front of various Japanese landmarks, and the curious images have generated significant online interest.

Paul Downton's dismissal as England's managing director has shifted focus to the county cricket season and Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England team. Pietersen, posing for the Surrey team photo, displayed a range of emotions, from deep thought to joviality. His rejoining Surrey is an attempt to force his way back into the Test set-up after being controversially axed in 2014, with Downton's sacking potentially paving the way for his international return ahead of the Ashes series.

Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has sacked its Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week following a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Owner Angelo Massone had initially fired and then reinstated Ze Maria days earlier but dismissed him again after the defeat, which left the team in 16th place and six points from safety. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international, had been the club's third coach this season and will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets his unsuccessful loan move to Manchester United, where he has only scored four goals and is unlikely to be signed permanently for £46 million. Dirar states that while Falcao was unhappy during his time in Monaco, he would have played in the Champions League had he stayed, suggesting it would have been a better option for him than his current struggles at United following a serious knee injury.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a very tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, making off with the cash register till and approximately $1500. The offender, who wore a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt, demanded cash from the owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop. No weapons were seen, and the suspect remains at large. Police have asked anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for a second time on Monday. She was initially arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15-year-old student, admitting to kissing him and letting him touch her breasts. She was released on bail, suspended from teaching, and put on administrative leave. A second 15-year-old student then accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January in her car. After an investigation prompted by school rumors, she was arrested again on the new charges and released after posting a $50,000 bail.

A large crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, was captured on video swimming through a public marina with a dead pet dog, which belonged to a local bike shop owner, clamped in its jaws. The incident, witnessed by tourist Tim Weston, occurred after the curious dog approached the water's edge near a crocodile sanctuary. The crocodile held onto its catch for hours as onlookers watched. The viral video, viewed over 500,000 times, drew horrified reactions, though crocodiles are common in the area due to urbanisation encroaching on their mangrove habitat.

Despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton, Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident he can keep the club in the Premier League, believing eight or nine wins might be enough to survive. Currently two points above the relegation zone with six difficult games remaining, Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players but is convinced the team will get the results needed to avoid relegation. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory moved them to fifth, though manager Ronald Koeman was left to address an internal issue after Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty against team rules.

Teacher Ian Guffick was banned from teaching for at least two years after he altered pupils' SATs exam answers and allowed them to make changes outside of test conditions at Mitton Manor Primary School. An investigation found this to be unacceptable professional conduct, which led to the Department for Education annulling all of the school's 2014 SATs results. Although the panel found his actions were deliberate and dishonest, they fell short of fraud, and he was considered remorseful.

The 13 iconic 10-foot-tall blue letters from the original Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, receiving no bids despite a pre-auction estimate of $300,000 to $600,000. The letters were owned by Yankees Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who had purchased them after the stadium closed in 2008. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after Sterling was pictured inhaling nitrous oxide and both were seen with shisha pipes; neither player will be disciplined. Rodgers, who has Steven Gerrard available after suspension for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, did not confirm if he would recall the captain, instead focusing on the team's readiness to progress after recent near-misses in major competitions.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after playing in Germany's 2-0 Euro 2016 qualifier win against Georgia and posted a picture relaxing with his dog. After missing Arsenal's previous game due to illness, he is expected to start against Liverpool. Ozil has been in fine form since returning from injury, with four assists and three goals since January, and he claims he now fits in perfectly with the physical demands of English football.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu insists the club is very happy with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him, refuting speculation to the contrary. Bartomeu stated that Enrique, who is under contract until 2016, is fully focused on the team's performance, and the club is pleased as Barcelona remains in contention to win three trophies this season. This support was reiterated following a Champions League victory over PSG and a domestic win against Valencia, where goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi secured the result.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, worth approximately £100,000-a-week, which will run until the summer of 2020. As the vice-captain, his improved form with seven goals and 13 assists this season makes him a candidate to replace the departing Steven Gerrard as club captain. Henderson is the third key player, after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, to sign an extension, while talks with Raheem Sterling, who rejected a deal, are expected to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, despite struggling to secure the starting left back position at Chelsea, insists he is happy and wants to stay until the end of his three-year contract, contrary to interest from his former club Atletico Madrid. He also notes that manager Jose Mourinho is demanding full focus from the league-leading team for their nine remaining difficult Premier League games.

Nathan Hughes had his three-match ban for accidentally striking George North's head with his knee overturned on appeal, with the panel concluding the incident was an accident and no act of foul play occurred. The initial suspension, issued after Hughes was sent off for the collision that knocked North unconscious, had been widely criticized as excessive given the lack of intent. Hughes is now free to play immediately, while North has been advised to take a month off due to concussion symptoms, his third head injury in two months.

The intense red sunsets observed in Washington, Oregon, and British Columbia were caused by smoke from wildfires in Siberia. The fires, started by farmers but spread by strong winds, destroyed villages. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific Ocean, and its particles filtered out shorter wavelengths of sunlight, allowing only the longer red and orange wavelengths to pass through, creating the dramatic colorful effect at sunrise and sunset.

Becky Schoenig's brand new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her St. Louis driveway but was later recovered by police thanks to a tip from Mick Sexton. The thieves had modified the car with red rims, red side detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping" her car, though she later had it professionally cleaned to remove the strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. To honor Sexton, she created a smoothie called "The Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses, totaling around £12 million, if the club fails to qualify for the Champions League, a condition of their incentivized contracts designed to comply with financial fair play rules. After a defeat to Manchester United and a poor run of form that has seen the team lose seven times since being joint-top in January, they are in a battle for fourth place, holding a narrow lead over Liverpool. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team has performed poorly and thrown their season away, with the failure also potentially impacting their ability to attract world-class transfer targets like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under-18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a "mini-derby" at Altrincham's Moss Lane. The matchwinner was Callum Gribbin, who scored with a delightful free-kick. The game, which featured many local English players, was part of the Barclays Under-18s Premier League play-offs, leaving United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City lost both of their play-off matches. The match showcased significant skill and commitment, suggesting several talented players on both sides may deserve future first-team opportunities.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart, after earning his 50th international cap in a 1-1 draw with Italy, praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" and an inspiration. Hart, who is 10 years younger than the 37-year-old Buffon, stated he is still learning from him and aspires to continue playing well for both his club and country to earn more caps.

Chipotle is partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery in 67 cities, entering the $70 billion food delivery market. The service includes a 9% charge on top of delivery fees that start at $5. Other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also developing or testing delivery services. The passage also notes that presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio have recently been seen at Chipotle restaurants.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly pleaded with the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for the convicted bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. In a Boston Globe column, Bill and Denise Richard described the immense toll the attack took on their family, which included their son's death and their daughter's severe injuries. They stated that while they understand the brutality of the crimes, they support a sentence of life in prison without the possibility of release to avoid years of painful appeals that would force them to continually relive the tragedy. Their plea is to end the anguish and allow their family and Boston to move forward.

A mystery billionaire has commissioned a custom-built Boeing 747-8 into a £400 million luxury private home over three years. The jet, which normally carries 600 passengers, has been converted to include multiple lounges, a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a master bedroom, and an "aeroloft" with eight beds. It features hotel-like amenities such as a conference room, offices, and spaces for dozens of guests, creating a level of luxury far exceeding standard first-class commercial travel.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying a Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station, but its secondary goal of landing the rocket's first stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful as the rocket landed too hard and tipped over. This was the company's second failed attempt at such a landing, a technique it is pursuing to achieve rocket reusability and drastically reduce the cost of space access. The Dragon spacecraft will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker, and will later return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of cargo for a Pacific splashdown. This mission is the sixth SpaceX flight to the ISS.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness for the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas's Westgate Hotel, a location where Elvis performed. She collaborated with the Today show on a contest for an "Elvis-obsessed" couple to win this wedding, which includes a reception, a two-night hotel stay, airfare, and tickets to an Elvis show. The winning couple, announced on a Monday, will be married on April 23. Priscilla emphasized the chapel is a first-class, serious venture and not a joke, with no impersonators allowed. She was involved in designing the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis. Contest entrants had to submit a video or photos explaining why they deserved to win.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite being four points behind, following a 2-0 win over Newcastle. In that match, Henderson equalled the appearance record for top European leagues with his 47th game. The victory, with goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, was a response to recent poor results, and Henderson feels continued wins could pressure City. Newcastle had a strong penalty appeal denied when Dejan Lovren fouled Ayoze Perez, which Allen admitted looked like a spot-kick.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak with a 1-0 Serie A victory over Napoli, moving them four points ahead of Lazio in second place. Miralem Pjanic scored the decisive goal from a counter-attack in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves to secure the win. The match was played under tight security due to past fan violence, with no incidents reported. Napoli's winless run extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a goalless draw in a dull League One match, described as testing the patience of fans. Due to the lack of action, Doncaster's media team compiled match highlights that were only 27 seconds long, featuring just 14 seconds of footage showing the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man named Roland Giroux has developed a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan. He films the fish willingly interacting with him, allowing itself to be cupped, stroked, and massaged by his hand inside the tank, often resting motionless between his fingers. The fish even follows his hand to the surface when he leaves. Giroux cultivated this bond by hand-feeding the fish after removing two other fish that were bullying it. The fish now enjoys daily 15-minute play sessions and becomes frustrated if they are missed.

Ben Stokes, a fiery and aggressive character in the England cricket team, is back after a year of ups and downs, with his return to the Kensington Oval serving as a reminder of his past incident of punching a locker. While his natural exuberance and aggression are valued assets that can produce runs and wickets, they require careful man-management, as demonstrated by coach Peter Moores successfully advising him after a clash with Marlon Samuels. England wants to play him as much as possible to help him reach his full potential, accepting there will be lows with the highs, as long as his aggression is controlled and channeled correctly.

Wales' crucial Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at the Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000-seat sell-out. Both teams lead Group B with 11 points, though Belgium is ahead on goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel has raised expectations for qualification, generating high ticket demand. The match will not be moved to the larger Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules prohibiting venue changes within 120 days of the game, and it is understood the Welsh squad prefers the Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has named his 18-man squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where they are the defending champions. The team, which qualified with a perfect record, is in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, with notable call-ups for Arsenal's Stephy Mavididi and Chris Willock (his first time), and recalls for Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold.

Manchester City are pursuing the signing of 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the club's top youth talents and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. The player previously rejected a move to Barcelona's academy at age 12 to continue his studies. City have held discussions with Anderlecht's chairman to agree on a compensation package as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to build for the future.

A man has been arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, who was found strangled and beaten in a Fulham flat on March 28th. She died from injuries to her head and neck. The arrested 23-year-old man has been bailed pending further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward, as she had worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami.

A woman named Dawn, who had suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to confront her family friend and housemate, Jamie, a convicted burglar, about stealing £207 she and her partner had saved for a gravestone for one of her lost babies, Daniel James. After initially denying it, Jamie failed a lie detector test confirming he took the money. It was also revealed he had sent Dawn a Facebook message confessing and blaming his girlfriend, Carol. Dawn expressed feeling utterly betrayed, as the money was intended as a final gesture of love for her son.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women, children, the ill, and elderly, with the assistance of Arab tribal leaders. The freed individuals were received by Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. This event is part of the ongoing persecution of the Yazidi minority, whom ISIS targeted with extreme cruelty, including mass killings, enslavement, and rape, after overtaking their towns in northern Iraq the previous summer. This created a major humanitarian crisis that prompted international intervention, including airstrikes by a U.S.-led coalition.

Harry Kane, having had a remarkable breakthrough season with Tottenham and the England national team, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animated video by Copa90, created using layered still photographs, highlights his best goals and celebrations from the season, including strikes against Chelsea and Arsenal and his goal on his England debut. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of the awards ceremony where he is a contender alongside players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to manage Liverpool despite a trophy-less season and a likely failure to finish in the top four, arguing that a manager's future should not be determined by one game. He states that Rodgers must identify areas for improvement and make the right signings to succeed next season. Separately, Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work through his 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in schools in deprived areas of Merseyside.

At East Midlands Airport, four-year-old James Hayward had his brightly colored plastic Nerf gun confiscated by security, who deemed it a security risk and also frisked him. His father criticized the staff as "over-zealous" and "ludicrous" for the action, but the family surrendered the toy to avoid missing their flight to Lanzarote. The airport apologized for the inconvenience and noted they had offered to post the toy back, but defended the decision by stating government regulations prohibit any items that resemble a prohibited weapon, such as a replica or model gun. The family later bought James a replacement toy.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. Identifying himself only as "Rich," a 31-year-old with an athletic build, tattoos, and who does not drink or smoke, he listed his requirements for a partner. A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a mammal migration record by swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous humpback whale record. He was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships but saw limited playing time, including just three minutes at Euro 2016. He is also England's most-capped Under-21 player with 46 appearances and scored his sole international goal in a 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped their Glovertown home after it was completely destroyed by a fire, though their dog and cats perished. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, a routine act that this time caused the kitchen to be engulfed in flames within seconds. The fire alarm did not sound. Her son David woke the family after seeing the flames while on a FaceTime call, an action his mother credits for saving her and her daughter's lives. The community has donated essential items to the family, who fled with only their pyjamas. Mrs. Smith is immensely proud of her son, who does not yet grasp the significance of his heroic act.

The energy drinks giant Red Bull was reportedly considering a £200m offer for West Ham United, a club majority-owned by David Sullivan and David Gold since their 2010 purchase that valued it at £105m. The club has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups following its move to the London Stadium. While Sullivan previously stated a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, he and Gold intended for their ownership to pass to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards, described as an unofficial platform for summer blockbuster promotion, saw *The Fault in Our Stars* win Best Movie; its star Shailene Woodley won Best Female Performance, the Trailblazer Award, and Best Kiss. Bradley Cooper won Best Male Performance for *American Sniper*, Channing Tatum won Best Comedic Performance, and Meryl Streep won Best Villain. Kevin Hart received the Comedic Genius Award, and Robert Downey Jr. was honored with the Generation Award by his *Avengers* co-stars. The ceremony also featured previews for upcoming summer films.

St Mirren manager Jack Ross has signed 21-year-old Cammy Smith on loan from Aberdeen, describing the move as a "brilliant acquisition." Ross, who did not expect to secure the player from Dundee United, praised Smith as a good and mature player who will provide another attacking option. Smith, a Scotland Under-21 international, made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four goals in 89 appearances for the club; he has five goals this season while on loan at United. St Mirren, who are bottom of the Championship, play Falkirk next.

Northumberland County Council announced that warmer weather has allowed its Jetpatcher machines to begin repairing potholes, with a goal of filling 145 potholes daily over the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to fix drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and to clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors on EnQuest's Thistle platform were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework without proper protective equipment. The workers, who were not immediately informed, now face cancer fears and are undergoing medical tests. The incident was not reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) as the exposure level was below the threshold, and no HSE investigation was conducted. EnQuest stated it has since taken additional precautionary steps, while Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety. The workers and their union, Unite, have criticized the companies' handling of the incident and lack of transparency.

The Asian Civilisation Museum in Singapore is returning a $650,000 sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India. The artwork was purchased in 2007 from the New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to trafficking stolen antiquities. Although there is no definitive proof this specific piece was stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu, the museum decided to return it following a confession by the dealer's manager and an official request from India's Archaeological Survey of India. The museum, which bought 30 objects from the dealer, will pursue legal action to seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with its epicenter in Garfagnana. It was felt in several major cities, including Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. While there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, phone lines and power were cut in the Garfagnana area, schools were evacuated as a precaution, and several aftershocks were felt. An official described it as a "fairly shallow" and "medium-strong" quake typical for the area, which is prone to earthquakes. This event recalls a deadly magnitude-6 quake in the same region in May 2012 that killed over 20 people, as well as the 2009 L'Aquila quake that killed nearly 300, for which scientists were convicted of manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring statements ahead of the disaster.

The fruit is still attached to the plant and is not yet ripe enough to eat. Austin Grant from Sheffield had been dubious about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate, but has finally seen some results.

Rockstar has delayed the release of its game from January 27th to March 24th, stating the extra weeks are needed for testing and polish to ensure quality. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC version. Screenshots for the PC edition were released, highlighting improved detail, 1080p resolution at 60fps, support for up to 4K, and triple monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications have been published. The game previously set an entertainment sales record by generating $1 billion in revenue within three days of its initial September 2013 release.

The 76-year-old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)", a painting about 7ft in height that depicts a leper squint from a medieval church. A longlisted artist on three previous occasions, Simpson stated the prize money would be spent on art materials. Judge Ansel Krut praised the "difficult" but "extraordinary" and "technically subtle" painting, calling it "a little like a tone poem" that builds a picture over time. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards.

The offices of two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked simultaneously by masked assailants in the early hours of Thursday. The attackers used guns, shattering windows and leaving bullet casings at both scenes, which are 20km apart. Firefighters extinguished a blaze at Yeni Safak, and no casualties were reported. Police have cordoned off the areas and are hunting the assailants, though no group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with Mansfield Town (the Stags) and on loan at Crawley where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, has agreed to join Grimsby Town (the Mariners) on a free transfer. The move, which is manager Marcus Bignot's first signing for the club, will be made official on 1 January.

Arsene Wenger, linked with the England managerial position, stated he is focused on his current job at Arsenal and supported interim manager Gareth Southgate, saying he is a good observer with a chance to prove his competency. Southgate has upcoming matches to secure the role permanently. A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police, who are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, stated the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

A new charter arrangement will see freight services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month, ending a dispute over seafarers' pay on the Hellier and Hildasay vessels, which were operated by contractor Seatruck. The RMT union had claimed some workers were paid less than £4 an hour, as Seatruck argued the minimum wage did not apply to its non-UK crew. Under the new agreement, all crew members will be paid at least the UK minimum wage, resolving the issue on this heavily subsidised Scottish government route.

Ken Dickie died in hospital six days after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, with whom Dickie had been in a relationship. Both men, who had been drinking, had a confrontation outside a bar. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault, and he and his mother also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially lying to police about the events. They will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter behind major hits for Michael Jackson and Heatwave, has died in London at age 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, Temperton wrote iconic songs including "Thriller," "Rock With You," and "Boogie Nights." He began his career after answering an ad for the band Heatwave while working in a frozen food factory. His work with producer Quincy Jones on Jackson's "Off the Wall" and "Thriller" albums was pivotal, helping make "Thriller" the best-selling album of all time in the US. A Grammy winner and two-time Oscar nominee, Temperton was widely celebrated by fellow musicians for his genius and prolific songwriting.

A team including researchers from Swansea, Exeter, Reading, and Brazilian universities discovered over 450 ancient, geometrical earthworks, or geoglyphs, in the Brazilian Amazon that are approximately 2,000 years old. The function of these sites is unclear, but they were likely used only sporadically as ritual gathering places, not as villages or defensive structures. Analysis of soil samples indicates they were built within a forested environment and were not visible above the canopy, unlike other monumental sites. The research also challenges the idea of a pristine Amazon, instead finding evidence that humans managed the forest for thousands of years by cultivating valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of resources, a practice that may have left a legacy on modern biodiversity.

Nick Kyrgios defeated Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in the first round of the Shanghai Masters, attributing his quiet and tired demeanor to fatigue from his recent Japan Open win and the long travel to the venue. He also referenced a previous fine he received at the same tournament the year before for a foul-mouthed outburst.

The human papilloma virus (HPV) jab, currently given to girls in Wales to protect against cervical cancer, is being advocated by scientists and charities to also protect against head and neck cancers. Charities and medical organizations are calling on the Welsh government to extend the vaccination to boys, citing a rise in cases that are increasingly affecting younger men who are non-smokers. While the Welsh government is awaiting recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation, advocates urge immediate action to address this public health issue, noting that HPV causes 5% of global cancers.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old from West Lothian, passed away from a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He had documented his fight against the disease on a popular Facebook page called Jak's Journey. Despite receiving news in January that his cancer was terminal and treatment had stopped, he maintained a positive attitude. His story touched many, and he was able to briefly attend a school prom held in his honor just before his death, where he received awards. His family has been raising money for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a match with few chances, with Mohamed Salah assisting Abdallah El Said for a late 89th-minute winner. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside earlier in the second half. The result means Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is eliminated from the tournament. Lancashire County Council has identified land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College sites as the preferred location for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a town without a station since 1956. This decision, made in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, follows a comparative study of potential sites. Police discovered an elaborate cannabis grow house during a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was seriously injured in Hamelin after being dragged by the neck through several streets. The 10-year-old racehorse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old 5,000m indoor record by 14 seconds with a time of 14:49.12. The council's chief executive thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants, later claimed by the Islamic State (IS), attacked a Kabul hospital using explosives and gunfire, killing staff and patients before being killed by commandos after a hours-long siege; over 50 people were wounded. This marked a shift in IS tactics in Afghanistan, as it was their first direct engagement with security forces in the capital using a method more commonly associated with the Taliban, suggesting an expansion of their military capabilities. The Taliban denied involvement. The attack was condemned by the Afghan president as a violation of all human values.

English rider Guy Martin crashed at the TT and will not race Hondas for the remainder of the year, citing the bike's lack of competitiveness and mechanical problems. He clarified he is not quitting road racing entirely but has no plans to race the Honda again after it felt like being a test rider. His team withdrew him from the Ulster Grand Prix without telling him, a decision he is okay with. Martin stated he has no unfinished business and now wants to focus on racing classic bikes and "oddball stuff."

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared gubernatorial posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999 and reinforcing its decline after losing the presidential election. The PDP, now reduced to a regional party with most wins in the south-east, lost key northern states for the first time but held Rivers State. The APC failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari as militant groups there could disrupt crucial oil revenue. While the elections were marred by violence in some areas, they were more peaceful overall than in previous years. The PDP's loss is attributed to voter desire for change after its 16-year rule, which was hit by defections and allegations of corruption.

A US environmental group, Mighty, accuses the agricultural trader Olam and its major stakeholder, Singapore's Temasek, of potentially encouraging unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to the haze affecting Southeast Asia. The report claims Olam created a secretive market for rogue suppliers and that Temasek's investment links Singapore to the problem. Both companies reject the allegations; Olam defends its strict "no burn" sourcing policy and commitment to removing non-compliant suppliers, while Temasek states it does not direct Olam's operations but supports no-burn policies. The report also accuses Olam of destructive practices in Gabon, to which Olam responded that its partnerships are responsible and transparent, supporting Gabon's right to convert a small amount of forest land for agriculture.

Fernando Forestieri is a doubt due to a knee injury that has limited him to substitute appearances, while David Nugent could return from a groin problem. Jacob Butterfield is hoping for a recall after scoring a late equalizer as a substitute.

Pakistan's telecommunications regulator lifted the ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed all internet service providers to restore access. The government stated that a process is now in place for the PTA to request Google directly to block offending material, which Google may restrict after a thorough review. However, YouTube clarified that government removal requests are not automatically granted and will be subject to its own guidelines and review process, with such requests recorded in its Transparency Report. The ban was originally imposed in 2012 following protests over the "Innocence of Muslims" film, which was deemed blasphemous. Some activists are calling for greater transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces calls to resign from Liberia's FA president Musa Bility because Scala shares Swiss-Italian nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility cites an electoral regulation barring committee members with a conflict of interest and has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not step down by Thursday. Scala's spokesman argues no conflict exists as the rules do not prohibit shared nationality with a candidate and that Scala's withdrawal in the 2015 election was a voluntary, precautionary measure because the Swiss candidate was the incumbent president. The election to replace Sepp Blatter, involving five candidates, is scheduled for 26 February in Zurich.

Two men, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed in an explosion at Harford Attachments on Monday morning while working in a paint-spraying area. Evidence suggests a flashover explosion occurred from a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, causing a fireball. A forensic search has been conducted, and the Health and Safety Executive is involved in the investigation.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations for lodging complaints against CAF after a controversial refereeing decision in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea; they apologized to resolve the issue. Separately, Morocco's ban from the 2017 qualifiers was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), which also reduced a fine from $1 million to $50,000; the ban was initially imposed after Morocco refused to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola fears. Both nations have since been included in the qualifying draw, with Tunisia in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

Following a mass brawl during the Manchester City versus Chelsea match, the Football Association charged both clubs with failing to control their players. The incident occurred after a dangerous challenge by City's Sergio Aguero, who received a four-match ban. City's Fernandinho was also sent off and banned for three games for his involvement, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas faced no further action. Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola apologized, and both clubs were given a deadline to respond to the charge.

Wales has some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. A pilot scheme in Cynon Valley and Neath focuses on patients suspected of having cancer but without urgent symptoms, aiming to speed up diagnosis and avoid treatment delays. The scheme, inspired by a Danish model seen to improve survival rates, allows GPs to refer such patients to a diagnostic center for multiple tests on the same day within seven days. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms in the Cwm Taf area receive a prompt diagnosis. The goal is to reach patients with less obvious symptoms earlier. A similar clinic will be established in Neath Port Talbot. If the six-month pilot is successful, other local health boards will offer the service.

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series with their second-biggest win over Pakistan by runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his first-innings 254, an unbeaten 71 in the second, four catches, and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook and pundits Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott praised England's performance and Root's exceptional, controlled innings, which came after poor shots in the first Test. Pakistan's batting was criticized for poor shot selection and a lack of confidence, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far. While Boycott predicted further England wins, Vaughan believed the series would remain very tight.
