Hull City came from behind to beat Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. After Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton ahead, Hull lost two strikers to first-half injuries. Substitute Robert Snodgrass transformed the game, scoring the equalizer and then providing an assist for Michael Dawson's headed winner within two second-half minutes. Despite Southampton's pressure for an equalizer, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made crucial saves and Sam Clucas produced a remarkable last-minute goal-line clearance to secure the victory.

A fatal collision occurred around 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, resulting in the death of a local motorcyclist. The tractor driver involved was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police have appealed for witnesses and closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road and A158 Jubilee Way junctions.

Macedonian President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, stating he wanted to "put an end to the agony" and defend national interests ahead of early elections. His decision was condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and prompted protests, and by EU officials who warned it threatened Macedonia's EU membership ambitions and was not in line with the rule of law. The country's political crisis began in 2015 with the release of recordings allegedly showing government ministers plotting vote-rigging and a murder cover-up; the government denies the accusations and has accused Zaev of destabilizing the nation.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's next match as the club seeks a new manager, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis expressed the urgent need for an appointment to avoid relegation, which he fears would be catastrophic, citing the Championship's increased strength and the club's potential inability to retain top players. He believes the club has lost its identity, the "Swansea Way," since Michael Laudrup's 2014 departure, due to frequent management changes and a failure to adequately replace key players. Despite this, Curtis maintains the current squad is capable of survival and educates new signings on the club's remarkable history, from near-bankruptcy and relegation to establishing a Premier League reputation, to emphasize the importance of staying up.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after a 3-2 defeat to Leyton Orient, a result that ended their slim survival hopes and kept Orient's play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who were promoted to the Football League in 2007 and reached League One in 2010, will now return to the National League under manager John Still, who previously led them up the leagues. The club struggled defensively, conceding many more goals than the previous season, and offensively, with top scorer Jamie Cureton netting far fewer goals. Orient's victory came just days after their player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed, with interim manager Andy Hessenthaler stating the need to win games for the play-offs. John Still cited a lack of organization and discipline for the loss and is committed to gaining promotion next season.

Steven Gerrard, the 36-year-old former Liverpool and England captain, is returning to Liverpool FC in February as a youth coach, marking his first role since retiring as a player. Manager Jürgen Klopp, who had a long discussion with Gerrard, described the appointment as wonderful news and supports Gerrard's ambition to become a manager, believing he has a bright future. Gerrard, who retired after a 19-year career that included winning the Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup, and three League Cups with Liverpool, had been linked with the MK Dons managerial job but felt it came too soon; he is currently working towards his UEFA A coaching licence.

Morton secured a comfortable home victory, opening the scoring through a close-range goal from McManus and quickly doubling their lead with a deflected strike from Ross Forbes. Alloa reduced the deficit before half-time with a goal from Kyle McAusland, but Morton extended their lead in the second half with another finish from McManus and a late goal from Denny Johnstone.

Ofsted has found children being taught in squalid conditions in three now-closed Birmingham locations, part of an investigation into 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities. Running an illegal school carries a potential 51-week jail term, and the government is consulting on stricter regulations for places teaching over 6-8 hours a week. Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw believes these cases are the "tip of the iceberg," with children at risk of abuse or radicalization. He criticized officials for providing confusing advice and has been tasked with preparing cases for prosecution. The government is funding a dedicated inspection team, and the Education Secretary emphasizes that these rules and actions will apply to all religious groups operating such unsafe, unregistered schools.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh and is the region's first new distillery in nearly 200 years. It is a small-scale operation, using one of the UK's smallest production stills located in a cowshed. The gin aims to capture the local flavour by using botanicals from the surrounding Teviot valley, aligning with the ethos of the on-site Scottish Borders Brewery. The distillery is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders heroine from the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, a choice that reflects both the local landscape and the strong female production team.

Gary Green, who was over twice the legal alcohol limit after consuming the equivalent of 13 pints, reversed a tractor into Harry Whitlam on private land at Swithens Farm in August 2013, killing him. Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting a health and safety offense, as the incident occurred on private property. Harry's mother stated the family had been changed forever and hoped to remember the good times. The HSE inspector described Green's behavior as reckless.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has partially upheld Luis Suarez's appeal against his FIFA ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the World Cup. While his nine-match international competitive ban remains, the court ruled the four-month suspension from all football-related activities was excessive. Suarez is now permitted to train with his new club Barcelona, play in friendly matches for both club and country, and attend matches and promotional activities. His competitive debut for Barcelona is likely to be on 26 October. The court's full reasoning will be published later, and the players' union Fifpro expressed disappointment that the sanctions were not reduced further.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race by defeating the Lithuanian pair Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. They credited their victory to a week of dedicated training. The 380-meter course involved obstacles like haystack hurdles, a steep slope, and water pistols. The event was open to all pair combinations, not just married couples, and included men carrying women, men carrying men, and a woman carrying a woman. As winners, Rich and Anna qualified for the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond, the minister, addressed concerns about potential job losses at the DVLA when the paper car tax disc is replaced with an electronic system in October 2014, a change announced by Chancellor George Osborne. In a letter to Mike Hedges, Hammond stated that while job roles would change and some positions would be reduced due to fewer refunds and new processes, any decreases in staff numbers would be managed by redeploying employees to other growing areas of the business rather than through redundancies. Mike Hedges welcomed these assurances, believing they would comfort DVLA employees, and acknowledged the advantages of the new system, including paying by monthly direct debit.

Hungary's government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has refused to backtrack on three contentious laws concerning asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, which the EU objects to. The Foreign Minister stated these are domestic issues and that Poland has pledged to veto any EU attempt to strip Hungary of its voting rights, a process that requires unanimity. The laws include tight asylum controls, a higher education law threatening the closure of the Central European University, and a draft bill that would stigmatize NGOs as "foreign-backed." The EU has warned of potential action if no positive developments occur.

Emma Watson stars as Belle in Disney's live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast," with Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Kevin Kline plays Maurice, and the film is directed by Bill Condon. It began filming in May at Shepperton Studios for a US release on 17 March 2017.

Adrian Gill, a renowned and controversial columnist for The Sunday Times, has died after being diagnosed with a widespread cancer, which he had humorously referred to as the "full English." His editor, Martin Ivens, described him as a "giant among journalists" and the "heart and soul" of the paper, praising his dazzling, fearless writing and wit. Gill, who was dyslexic and dictated his columns, was known as a brilliant but provocative writer whose articles often caused outrage, including comments about the Welsh, a Norfolk pub, and a review that led to censure for describing Clare Balding as a "dyke on a bike." He was married twice, first to author Cressida Connolly and then to future Home Secretary Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children. At the time of his death, he was engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, with whom he also had two children.

During a performance in Ulan Bator, Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar (Amraa) was allegedly attacked, with reports stating he was hit on the head with a bottle and kicked in the face, leaving him in a coma for about 10 days with serious brain injuries. He was wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a pre-Hitlerian symbol of eternity in the country. The Russian embassy is investigating but called local press reports "distorted." The suspect is an unidentified Russian diplomatic officer. Mongolian police stated the officer was not detained because the injury was deemed not serious, denying diplomatic immunity was a factor. The rapper's father and lawyer denied reports he shouted "Heil Hitler" and demanded the suspect be investigated under Mongolian law.

On Monday, activists from Plane Stupid protested against airport expansion by occupying the northern runway at 03:30 BST; they were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area and are due in court on 19 August, while police stated airport security would be reviewed.

In a County Championship match, Glamorgan, led by stand-in captain Michael Hogan, scored 220, dominated by Nick Selman's 101, his second first-class century which ended a run of poor form. Seam bowlers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in favorable bowling conditions. Gloucestershire then struggled in their reply against a strong bowling attack, ending the day with the match evenly poised. Both Selman and Taylor expressed satisfaction with their performances, with Selman noting the difficulty of opening in English conditions and Taylor acknowledging the challenge ahead for his side's batsmen.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested after making online threats to a crisis center in Tennessee while drunk, admitting to planning a false crime report to lure police into an ambush on the Dee Estuary where he intended to shoot them. He was remanded in custody with a previous firearm conviction, and his defense claimed he never intended to carry out the threats. The police were especially concerned as he was on bail for firearms offenses at the time, for which he was later cleared.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 19 runs in a one-day match. After a poor start, Surrey recovered to 255-7 thanks to a 130-run partnership between Steven Davies (who scored 90) and Ben Foakes. Yorkshire's chase was derailed by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker that removed key batsmen Jonny Bairstow and Gary Ballance. Despite a 68 from Tim Bresnan, Yorkshire were bowled out for 236. Both captains commented on the match, with Surrey's Gareth Batty praising the decisive partnership, and Yorkshire's Alex Lees lamenting his team's failure to perform when it mattered.

A 56-foot converted trawler, located six miles west of South Stack, issued a distress call to coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting that its onboard pump was unable to handle the incoming water. The Holyhead RNLI lifeboat crew responded, provided an additional pump, and successfully towed the vessel to the safety of Holyhead.

Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to a scheduling conflict with her final-year veterinary medicine exams in May. The Scottish middle-distance runner, who recently set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m and finished fourth in the 1500m at the World Championships, expressed disappointment but prioritized completing her degree. She is considering competing in the World Indoor Championships in March and believes she has the potential to compete in at least two more Olympics.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are currently far from mounting a serious title challenge, primarily due to a significant drop in goalscoring and work-rate following the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. He criticizes the club's transfer dealings, stating the new strikers are not good enough and lack the intensity of the previous attack, which is causing the team to start games poorly. The defense, despite heavy investment, remains a weakness without a clear leader, and the team is no longer able to outscore opponents as they did the previous season. Savage believes it will be difficult for Liverpool to beat Chelsea, who are on a different level. He also discusses Steven Gerrard's long-term future, stating that while the player faces a physical and mental battle due to his age, he remains one of Liverpool's most important players and has the desire to extend his career.

A £45 million educational campus will be built in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council intends to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus in honor of William McIlvanney, a renowned writer born and educated in Kilmarnock who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, a former English teacher, became a full-time writer in 1975, earning recognition as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir" for works like the Laidlaw trilogy, and was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster before his death in December.

An area near the Gourock swimming pool was evacuated and an exclusion zone was established after a British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s was discovered. Residents within 500 meters were advised to stay indoors and keep windows open, while a half-mile maritime exclusion zone disrupted ferry services and small boat traffic. Authorities, including the Royal Navy, stated the evacuation was precautionary due to the mine's deteriorated and uncertain state, and it was moved to a safer location for disposal.

UK Sport has allocated £345 million for the 2020 Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics, a £2 million decrease from the Rio cycle. This funding will be distributed to 31 sports, with the goal of winning 51-85 Olympic and 115-162 Paralympic medals. Several sports, including archery, fencing, and badminton, have had their funding completely removed, a decision Badminton England called "incomprehensible" despite winning a bronze medal in Rio. Cycling's funding was cut by over £4 million. UK Sport stated it must prioritize investment in sports with the highest medal potential, a strategy it defends as proven by past successes. Some team sports like basketball criticized the decision, arguing UK Sport is neglecting their development. Funding for new Olympic sports like skateboarding and baseball has not yet been confirmed and is subject to further review of their medal potential.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a new 90-room, six-storey hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (nine and seven storeys tall) with 122 units. The local planning council approved the project with a 7-3 vote, arguing it would boost tourism and provide housing for older people, despite receiving 49 letters of objection and strong opposition from English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society. The objectors stated the scale of the development would cause "severe harm" to the conservation area, as the existing buildings contribute to its historic character.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus serving with the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was murdered in Brecon on 8 May while off-duty. He was punched, beaten, and left unconscious by Jake Vallely, who had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and was boasting about being the "hardest man in Brecon" prior to the attack. Vallely was found guilty and will be sentenced on 8 December, while his friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the assault. The attack, described by police as a "despicable act," shocked the community. Pte Boyd's family paid tribute to him as a loving and promising young man, stating Vallely's actions created an unfillable void and unbearable pain, and that the true strength of Brecon was shown by the community's support, not by Vallely's violence.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by "mutual agreement" following a major error on election day where voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from the electoral lists. An independent investigation has been launched to review the incident and the arrangements for the upcoming EU Referendum. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes, though voters questioned the fairness of the result. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will serve as the temporary replacement. Mr. Travers, in a statement, believed the changes he implemented would allow the borough to thrive, and the council acknowledged his valuable contribution.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1, with Josh Gillies scoring the opening goal from a free-kick before Wrexham's Sean Newton equalized with another set-piece. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead with a header from a cross. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half performance and the quality of the winning goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half form and their inability to convert chances.

The 2014 Global AgeWatch Index, which measures the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, ranked Norway as the best country and Afghanistan as the worst, with Mozambique being the second worst.

A network of at least 600, and eventually over 2,000, satellites is being built by Airbus and OneWeb to deliver global broadband, with a focus on connecting every school. This requires a revolutionary shift from traditional, expensive satellite manufacturing to a high-volume, low-cost assembly line model, aiming to produce units for under a million dollars each. Over 20 Soyuz rockets have been booked to launch the constellation, with the first satellites scheduled for April and a goal of nearly 300 in orbit by late 2020. OneWeb has raised $1.7bn in equity and is seeking further financing. The project, licensed by the UK, commits to debris mitigation by de-orbiting satellites within two years. While this new approach is disruptive, it is not expected to replace the need for bespoke, specialized satellites for certain missions.

Mr Swinney stated the UK government's spending review placed unprecedented pressure on Scotland's finances, projecting a 12.5% real-terms cut to its discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11, with over £1bn in cuts still to come. He argued these cuts were a choice, not a necessity, and committed to protecting key priorities like schools, hospitals, and police. The UK government responded that Scottish ministers would have £390m more available next year, rising to £750m with an underspend, and that the block grant of nearly £30bn is a better deal than independence. Labour criticized the SNP's approach and called for a long-term budget with different tax decisions.

Standard accessible toilets are inadequate for many people with severe disabilities who require carer assistance or equipment like hoists, leading to stress, isolation, and feelings of being devalued. Campaigners are calling for Changing Places toilets—larger facilities with enhanced features—to be a compulsory requirement in building regulations for new large complexes like stadiums and shopping centres, rather than just a recommendation. While some venues have successfully installed them with positive results, logistical and financial barriers exist for existing buildings. The current UK count is 893, but an estimated quarter of a million people need them.

A group of Italian consumer organizations has filed a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of abusing its dominant market position by forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees through longer-than-average contracts, which allegedly prevents them from switching to competitors. This is claimed to result in poorer consumer choice and higher prices at franchise locations. The complaint is supported by the SEIU and European unions. McDonald's defends its practice as a principle of sharing risk and reward that creates business opportunities. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if it finds the allegations founded. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants, which generated $9.27bn in worldwide revenue for the company in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh was started by Bangor Elim Church to support 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, after he was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign, which began on Facebook and Instagram, went viral with a single update being shared 948 times and seen by over 79,000 people worldwide. A mystery donor subsequently paid for a large billboard with the hashtag to be erected in Holywood. The campaign has provided significant support to Josh and his family, amazing the church's pastor with its global reach.

The UK government's military reorganization involves closing Brecon Barracks, a historic site operating since 1805, a decision condemned by local MP Chris Davies for its lack of respect for history and potential impact on the town's military tourism and high unemployment. While civilian and military jobs are not thought to be at risk, a petition has been launched against the closure. The plan includes creating a new light infantry centre at St Athan, closing Cawdor Barracks in 2024, and a Sennybridge depot in 2025. The Labour shadow defence secretary acknowledged the need for restructuring but warned of the uncertainty closures cause for local livelihoods.

A House of Lords report warns that the UK fishing industry, which voted heavily for Brexit to escape the EU's Common Fisheries Policy, risks being marginalized in wider negotiations despite its small GDP contribution. The report notes that a successful industry requires continued access to the EU market for exports, but this may come at the price of allowing EU boats more access to UK waters. It also states that many elements of the CFP should be retained, with management based on scientific advice and international cooperation. While the report highlights the potential for four different management regimes post-Brexit, many in the industry remain optimistic about gaining control of UK waters and achieving sustainable management.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks detailing extensive US surveillance programs. According to the documents, the NSA had massive access to personal data, including phone records from companies like Verizon, and through the Prism program, potential "backdoor" access to servers of major tech firms like Google and Facebook, though the companies denied involvement. US officials defended the programs as vital for national security, arguing they prevent terrorism, while critics and experts questioned their scope and power. The leaks highlighted that data protection laws vary by country, and data stored in the US, even for non-US citizens, falls under US jurisdiction like the Patriot Act, making it accessible to American authorities. The UK government refused to confirm or deny its involvement, and the EU expressed concern. Snowden stated he leaked the information because he found the surveillance horrifying and did not want to live in a society where all actions are recorded.

OpenAI is a venture backed by prominent figures like Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, as well as companies including Infosys and Amazon Web Services. Its research, free from financial obligations, is focused on creating a positive human impact from artificial intelligence. The organization's stated aim is to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity, unconstrained by the need for financial return. While some scientists, like Stephen Hawking and Elon Musk, have warned that AI is a significant existential threat that could surpass humans, other experts believe such a threat remains remote. OpenAI acknowledges the immense potential benefits of human-level AI but also the profound damage it could cause if built incorrectly, stating it should be an extension of human wills and distributed as broadly and safely as possible. Only a small portion of its pledged $1 billion funding will be spent in the immediate future.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, seriously injured in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch in June. Despite a brain injury that initially took his speech, he has shown immense determination, walking with crutches and an assistant. His nomination highlighted his unchanged personality and humor, and he dedicates time to fundraising for military charities like the Pilgrim Bandits. The event generated massive public support, resulting in over 5,000 Facebook friend requests and thousands of hits on his pages, which his mother described as phenomenal. This overwhelming response led to suggestions he create a public page. He was elated by the support and received hundreds of requests to appear with the torch.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty, remaining unchanged after three years of increases. The real median household income declined by 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking its first annual increase since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. This followed a record high poverty rate of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a new deal to remain with the club until 2019. A short-format specialist, he holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan. Lancashire's cricket director Ashley Giles praised Buttler as a talented cricketer whose presence was a factor in winning the previous T20 Blast final and a great, experienced influence on the squad. Buttler will return to the team from the Indian Premier League for Friday's T20 Blast game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates are for sale in Portsmouth, with no preservation bids received by the January deadline. Interested bidders are finalizing proposals, and a decision is expected in spring. The government aims to award at least one ship to a UK recycler to test the industry's capacity, though local MP Penny Mordaunt advocates for turning one into a reef for tourism. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions in Fiji, primarily between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, have caused significant instability through a series of coups. These events, including overthrows in 1987 and 2000, harmed the economy—especially tourism—and led to international isolation, such as Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to a lack of democracy. Following an agreement to hold elections in 2014, diplomatic ties were restored and Commonwealth membership was reinstated. The population is divided along ethnic lines with minimal mixing, and the economy, though diverse with sugar, tourism, and mining, is hampered by persistent deficits, making Fiji a major per capita recipient of aid.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated the country is committed to destroying its chemical weapons but missed a deadline, blaming attacks on a shipment by "terrorist groups" and citing the ongoing war. He denied government use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, contradicting activist groups who report hundreds of civilian casualties from such attacks. The government also denied that rebels had seized a central prison in Aleppo, though opposition groups claim control, stating it held thousands of detainees. The US expressed concern over the slow removal of chemical weapons, with only 4% of the stockpile shipped out, while Russia expects Syria to complete the transfer by March 1st for destruction by June. The OPCW acknowledged the process is slowed by security concerns.

Neel Mukherjee's *The Lives of Others* is the 5/2 favorite to win the Booker Prize, which is now open to all authors writing in English. The shortlist includes three British writers (including former winner Howard Jacobson), two Americans (Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler), and an Australian (Richard Flanagan). The novels cover diverse themes, from political unrest in 1960s Calcutta to a futuristic love story and a tale of a family with a chimpanzee sibling. Fowler's book is the best-selling on the list, with over 55,000 copies sold. A professor criticized the shortlist as weak, noting the omission of other notable novels and a debate over whether the prize should reward literary merit or readability. The winner will be announced at a ceremony in London.

A celebrity, PJS, is appealing to the UK Supreme Court to maintain an anonymity injunction against The Sun on Sunday, which wants to publish allegations of his extramarital activities. An interim injunction remains in place pending the Supreme Court's decision on whether to hear the appeal. The Court of Appeal had lifted the ban, ruling that despite PJS's efforts to remove online content, the story was already too widespread in the US, Scotland, and on the internet, making a permanent injunction a "hopeless task" as confidentiality had probably been lost.

Fosse Park, purchased for £345.5 million in August, is undergoing plans to improve its parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of its units. The new owners, who met with Blaby District Council, view the park as an investment and a key gateway into the city that currently presents an unsightly view. The director of investments stated the goals are to address the tired look of the park, the quality of common areas like walkways and parking, and the overall facilities to enhance the location.

A Disney film's release in Malaysia was delayed for a review due to its inclusion of a "gay moment." The Malaysian Censorship Board later approved the film for screening but required a "minor edit" to that scene, as homosexual activity is illegal in the country. The film was granted a P13 classification. While the Board stated its approval meant the film could be screened, a new release date has not been set, and local cinemas are offering refunds for pre-purchased tickets. The decision to review the film was met with significant criticism from netizens who found it ridiculous.

Landlords in Southampton must license properties housing more than three unrelated people as Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMO), but many avoid the £1,000 fee despite potential £20,000 fines, leaving an estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs. Tenants in these unregulated properties often face eviction fears and poor maintenance due to a shortage of affordable homes. Mandatory national licensing applies to larger HMOs (three storeys or five people), but Southampton's additional licensing scheme covers specific areas like Bargate and Shirley Freemantle. While most landlords cooperate, the council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny's Fine Gael and Micheál Martin's Fianna Fáil are attempting to avoid a second election, with Fianna Fáil offering to facilitate a minority government but not support its program. A major obstacle to their agreement is the issue of water charges; Fianna Fáil wants them immediately abolished while Fine Gael supports them, leading to a proposal for a commission to examine the future of Irish Water. This follows an election two months prior where no party achieved a majority, with Fine Gael holding 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, leaving TDs unable to elect a taoiseach.

The ferry Sorrento, owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire on a car deck while traveling to Valencia, approximately 27km from Mallorca. The fire became uncontrollable, forcing a full evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats, who were then rescued by another passenger ferry, the Puglia. At least three people were injured, with one seriously hurt, and taken to hospital by helicopter. The ship was in danger of sinking, and the rescued passengers were being returned to Palma de Mallorca, where psychologists would provide counselling. The cause of the fire was unclear.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs raised concerns about potential double voting, a criminal offence, and called for better integration of individual electoral registers to identify duplicates. A record 46.8 million people were registered for the 8 June election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. A surge in applications after the snap election was called resulted in 2.9 million submissions, but a net increase of only 1.4 million registrations indicated a significant proportion (30-70% in different areas) were duplicates. This was due to the lack of a direct link between the online registration service and local registers, making it difficult for people to check their status. The watchdog recommended clearer information on registration sites and a verification function. While there was no evidence to support claims of widespread double voting, the Commission stressed it is a serious offence. Labour warned against a blanket ban on being registered at two addresses, arguing it would disenfranchise students and others who need to be registered in two places for work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a 40-year-old former University of Nebraska football star and NFL player for the Rams, Dolphins, and 49ers, died by suicide in prison. His career and life were plagued by legal troubles, including convictions for assaulting his girlfriend and for driving his car into a group of teenagers, which resulted in a prison sentence of over 30 years. At the time of his death, he was being held alone and had just been ordered to stand trial for the murder of his cellmate. His former coach described him as intelligent but troubled by anger issues and personal demons.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier, was promoted to lance corporal by Brigadier Andrew Williams for good behavior at an event in Chester. He is the 30th ram mascot in a lineage dating back to the 1850s, with the first acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot in 1858. Joining the Mercian Regiment in 2014, he has his own army number, is paid for rations, and takes holidays during mating season at the Chatsworth Estate. His duties have included switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, coming back from a 3-1 deficit with late goals, including a stoppage-time winner from Dejan Lovren. The match, described as a classic, was a testament to manager Jurgen Klopp's philosophy of turning doubters into believers, echoing the spirit of Liverpool's 2005 Champions League final comeback. The Anfield atmosphere was highly emotional, featuring a tribute to the Hillsborough victims and a powerful rendition of "You'll Never Walk Alone." While the win showcased Liverpool's resilience and attacking talent like Divock Origi and Philippe Coutinho, it also exposed defensive vulnerabilities. The victory advances Liverpool to the semi-finals, moving them closer to a potential trophy and qualification for the Champions League.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, UK minister David Davis stated the government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland updated on Brexit negotiations through regular meetings to ensure a "two-way information flow" and get the best deal for the UK. Scottish minister Michael Russell welcomed the involvement but criticized the UK government's lack of transparency, stating its strategic intentions regarding single market or customs union membership remain unclear four months after the referendum, which he considers essential for Scotland's economy. Additionally, while the UK government hopes a High Court ruling on triggering Article 50 will be overruled, the Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four that are the genetic identical twin sisters of Dolly the sheep, are part of a long-term study to determine if cloned animals age normally or suffer from premature aging and associated diseases like osteoarthritis, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. The study, conducted by the University of Nottingham, involves exhaustive health assessments to see if Dolly's early death and arthritis were due to bad luck or an inherent problem with the cloning process, which might transfer cellular age-memory. The results, which could have profound implications for the science of cloning, are soon to be published, and the cloned sheep, now nine or ten years old, currently appear to be in very good health.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes on very soft ground, beating Vintage Folly. She will next race in the French Oaks at Chantilly over a mile and a quarter, while stablemates Enable and Coronet will contest the longer Epsom Oaks. Gosden expressed concern about the soft ground for his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes, a Derby trial, and will decide on his participation after walking the course. The short 16-day gap between the Dante and the Derby was also noted as a factor. In another race, Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas.

The British pound experienced significant volatility, initially falling against the dollar and euro before a partial recovery and then another decline, with its movement heavily influenced by polls showing a tightening race for the EU referendum. Investor uncertainty, measured by the volatility index, reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. This nervousness triggered a fall in Asian stock markets and a 1.1% drop in London's FTSE 100. Analysts predicted continued sterling volatility as the vote approached, with hedge funds betting on further declines. In contrast, Leave campaigners argued the pound was simply back to March levels and that a weaker currency benefited UK exporters.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point outside the playoff spots, after a loss that extended their losing run to three games. Despite this, manager Cowley was positive, praising his team's effort against a strong Barrow side and calling their season's performance so far remarkable. He acknowledged the significant challenge of being a part-time team but stated they would embrace and enjoy the difficult journey.

The most significant change described is the transfer of planning decision-making power from the central Planning Service to local councils in Northern Ireland, starting in April 2015, putting elected politicians in charge. Proponents view this as a positive democratic move that allows communities to shape their own development. However, critics, including Friends of the Earth, warn of potential dangers like a return to the discriminatory practices of the 1960s, citing the need for rigorous transparency and a strict code of conduct to prevent favoritism and close relationships between developers and political parties. The controversy extends to the debate over public disclosure of political donations, which some argue is essential for accountability but others oppose due to security concerns for donors.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, resulting in the amputation of her leg. Her owner found her injured in Winchburgh, and the Scottish SPCA is investigating. The charity and the owner condemned the act and urged witnesses to come forward. The incident was used by the Scottish SPCA to call for the urgent licensing of air guns, a measure that was previously consulted on by the Scottish government but opposed by 87% of respondents who deemed it too draconian.

Liverpool have signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for £32.5 million, making him their second most expensive player. The 24-year-old Belgian international, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, joins to address the team's lack of goals from last season. Manager Brendan Rodgers has added Benteke, along with other forwards Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino, to revive the attack after the club struggled following the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. Both Benteke's former manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge believe he will be a success, providing a strong, aggressive presence and scoring goals if he receives adequate service.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence that tablet devices improve academic results, as researchers could not isolate technology as the specific cause of any rise in attainment. However, the use of tablets in schools is widespread and growing rapidly, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them to some extent. The study highlighted that tablets help motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement when taken home, and head teachers reported a positive impact. A separate study suggested touch-screen computers are particularly useful for helping boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The research also showed how immersed young people are in technology, with many taking devices to bed for social media. The underlying trend is for increasing numbers of tablets in schools, with expectations for the number to rise from 430,000 to nearly 900,000 between 2014 and 2016.

The Museum of Liverpool's exhibition "Growing Up in the City" features 25 photographs from the 1880s to the 1990s, depicting the changing experiences of childhood in the city. Curator Kay Jones selected the images to show both the joys of play and special occasions, as well as the harsher reality of child labor. The pictures serve as a social history, illustrating how much life for children has transformed over more than a century.

Torquay United, known as the Gulls, have signed two players: centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, who joins from National League rivals Barrow after cancelling his contract, and 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, who was recommended by Micky Adams and arrives from Irish clubs subject to international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a needed leader and Keating as young, raw, but very hungry. The club is currently four points above the relegation zone with just one win in their last six games.

Bolivia has passed a new law permitting 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, a measure defended by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera as necessary to reflect the country's reality and economic needs, where over 500,000 children already work to support their families. The law also introduces harsher punishments, including a 30-year sentence for child homicide, and aims to eradicate extreme poverty. While the International Labour Organisation sets a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries and is studying whether the law breaches international regulations, the Bolivian government argues a stricter law aligned with international conventions would be unenforceable given the nation's characteristics.

A 50-year-old woman, later identified as actress Rosie O'Donnell, suffered a "widow maker" heart attack at her home. After experiencing chest aches, nausea, and fever, she searched her symptoms online, which confirmed they were signs of a women's heart attack. She took aspirin but did not call emergency services. The following day, a cardiologist inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. On her blog, she warned other women to know the symptoms, listen to their instincts, and call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington from Harrow was stabbed and killed in an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, at approximately 00:30 GMT after a group of youths tried to gain entry to the event. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police stated Che was an invited guest at a well-run party and was not involved in the initial altercation but was later targeted. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, while two boys aged 15 and 16 were arrested and bailed, and a 14-year-old was arrested on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

In response to poor cancer survival rates, Denmark reorganized its diagnostic system into three pathways to address long waiting times, particularly for patients with non-specific symptoms. A fast-track route handles clear cancer cases with strict time targets, while diagnostic centers provide comprehensive testing for unclear symptoms to prevent delays and "ping pong" between doctors. A third "yes-no" center offers quick scans for minor symptoms to rapidly identify the rare serious cases. This reorganization, achieved within existing resources, has not increased GP referrals but has led to better-organized care, improved survival rates, and is helping Denmark catch up to other European countries.

Powys council has been awarded a new role to regulate estate agents, replacing the disbanded Office of Fair Trading (OFT). It will receive £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching the Estate Agents Act. Complaints will still be made to local trading standards departments, which will then refer relevant cases to Powys for action.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to expand the roles of non-doctor staff, such as nurses and pharmacists, to cover tasks traditionally done by doctors, following a Nuffield Trust review that found this could help address doctor shortages and the rising demand for care of long-term conditions. While the report's author and NHS Employers see this as an opportunity to improve patient care and create more rewarding roles, unions and the British Medical Association warn it should not be a quick, cheap fix that compromises doctor training or replaces their expertise, and they note that funding for the necessary training is often unavailable.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing significant disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The road closure on the A36 was lifted at 14:00 GMT, and an investigation into the collision is underway. While First bus services had partially resumed a normal schedule, a full service was expected to return in time for the evening commute, with the managing director thanking the public and staff for their support.

Hmm, the user wants a concise summary of the passage about the Swansea tidal lagoon project, focusing on core information. The passage discusses a dispute between NRW and TLP over fish mortality estimates, with NRW citing higher numbers and TLP claiming they lack scientific basis. The project's cost, potential expansion, and government review are also mentioned. 

I need to stick strictly to the passage without adding anything. The summary should include the conflicting fish mortality figures, the disagreement over methodology, the project's cost and potential, and the government's ongoing review. 

The response should be a single paragraph without any introductory or concluding phrases. If I can't summarize, I must use the specific error phrase, but here the passage provides sufficient information. 

I'll structure it by first stating the conflict, then the figures from both sides, TLP's criticism, the project details, and the government's position.</think>Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated the Swansea tidal lagoon would cause significant annual fish mortality (21% of salmon, 25% sea trout), a claim developer Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed as having no "clear scientific basis" and being unrealistic. TLP stated its own modelling showed a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality and accused NRW of refusing to share its methodology. The £1.3bn project is a test case for larger lagoons, and while the Welsh Government is supportive, the UK government is still considering a review of the scheme's viability. NRW strongly disagreed with the criticism, stating its figures were based on the best available evidence assessed by independent experts.

Northern Ireland's DETI Minister Arlene Foster announced the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board, to provide strategic leadership for marketing and emulate the success of Scotland Food and Drink. The industry is described as hugely important with nearly 100,000 jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move as positive for export-led growth and better marketing coordination but noted it could have implications for other organizations, including her department, and looks forward to discussing the plans.

On Saturday afternoon, the public is invited to help plant thousands of trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, a project organized by the Woodland Trust. This is part of a four-year, UK-wide initiative to plant millions of native trees commemorating those who died in WW1, using the pledge "We will stand for those who fell." Specifically, the 40,000 trees at Brackfield are a tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives. The trust's director, Patrick Cregg, stated the goal is to create a place for wildlife and reflection, with wildflowers including poppies. Volunteers are advised to wear stout footwear, and limited parking is available near Derry city.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller about domestic violence that was praised as emotionally powerful, finely written, and well-plotted. The award was presented at the Harrogate crime writing festival, where Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career creating the groundbreaking female detective VI Warshawski, a character who changed perceptions of female protagonists and writers. Paretsky also founded Sisters in Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers.

Cricketer Mitch Santner, who broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, will rejoin the team after the 2017 ICC Trophy to make up for his lost time and impact with bat and ball, a move director Steve Rhodes called important for the team's qualification hopes; the county also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in a 2008 hit-and-run in Kiev by a speeding car with stolen license plates that did not brake. A UK coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating the evidence was overwhelming. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger and had married him after a four-day online courtship, did not attend the inquest. She had quickly tried to claim his assets after his death, and his family believes he was murdered in a staged accident so she could inherit his money. Ukrainian police have an active but not actively pursued murder inquiry into the case.

Charlie Fearns, a young boy from Merseyside, urgently needs experimental T-Cell Therapy in Seattle after a previous transplant failed and no treatment options remain for him in the UK. An anonymous donor has paid for the treatment in full, which his parents described as an overwhelming and incredible act of selfless generosity that left them ecstatic and extremely grateful. The family received confirmation of the donation via email from Seattle Children's Hospital, and with financial clearance granted, Charlie's treatment is scheduled to begin as soon as a start date is confirmed the following week.

In response to a celebrity photo hack involving third-party software that stole images from iCloud, Apple has implemented a security change to its two-step verification system. This update now requires the two-step process—which sends a code to a trusted device after a login attempt—to be used when accessing iCloud backups, a feature that was previously not protected in this way. While the system is an opt-in choice, an expert suggests it should be the default. The owner of the software used in the hacks, Elcomsoft, acknowledged that Apple's changes effectively block his tool and that users now get email notifications when a backup download starts. However, he expressed concerns that the 14-character recovery key could be lost or stolen. Another expert advocated for making two-factor authentication the default standard for all companies, not just Apple. Apple's CEO stated the company plans to more aggressively encourage users to turn on the feature and use stronger passwords, emphasizing the need for increased awareness.

Dan Groves stated that details of a deal for Mark Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town FC are still to be released, with The Sun reporting he will also become a club director. The club, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is comfortable investing £10,000 a week. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky. Wright, a 2011 I'm A Celebrity runner-up, has a history of playing non-league football.

MP Iain Wright, chair of the BIS select committee, has written to Mike Ashley giving him until 21 March to agree to give evidence in public at Westminster about the treatment of workers at his company's warehouse. The letter states that Ashley had invited the committee to a meeting at the company's base but has not accepted any of the alternative public hearing dates offered. The committee warned it reserves the right to pursue the matter further, including a complaint of contempt to the House of Commons, should he fail to agree to attend.

A report entitled "Putin. War," completed by associates of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, compiles publicly available evidence to accuse President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own political gain. It asserts that Russian army units, not volunteers, were decisive in securing key rebel victories in eastern Ukraine, with soldiers admitting they were directed there by Russian generals and were paid salaries. The report calculates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles and documents military units, though some evidence is hard to verify. The opposition accuses Putin of masterminding the war to boost his popularity, a strategy they admit was successful, but they face significant challenges in publishing and distributing the report to a Russian public where many are already aware of yet accept the country's involvement.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday; a post-mortem revealed the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearne died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, expressed frustration that the Welsh government was not consulted on the draft of the UK's Article 50 letter to the EU, calling it a sign of disrespect towards devolved administrations. While the UK government, represented by Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns, defended its actions by stating the Prime Minister had engaged with Wales and must act in the interests of the whole UK, the letter did promise a significant increase in devolved powers. However, the specific powers to be transferred, such as farming or economic aid, and crucially whether funding would follow, remain unclear and a point of contention, with Jones fearing no money would accompany the powers after 2020.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin stated he was appalled by the mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the community. Police reported they were carrying out duties when attacked and appealed to parents to know their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted as CEO following employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The company's court filing stated he violated sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, citing evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts, and the board deemed him unemployable due to the risk to the company. This was a response to Charney's defamation lawsuit, with his lawyer calling the statements false and an invasion of privacy. The company was also granted a restraining order preventing Charney from making negative statements or trying to remove board members.

The Great Britain (GB) basketball team will play a home game against Greece at the Copper Box in London, a rematch after a recent loss to Greece in Patras. This is GB's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017 tournament, serving as a key warm-up. Three players from the previous Greek game will be absent, giving GB a chance for revenge. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30-19:30 BST. After this, the team will travel to a tournament in Poland for their final preparations.

The author recounts being an early skeptic of the iPhone's 2007 launch, initially dismissing the hype before securing a brief hands-on demo for a news report, which some viewers criticized as excessive promotion. He later defended the coverage by comparing the iPhone's potential impact to the Model T Ford, a comparison he now believes is justified. A decade later, the author reflects that the smartphone has been a transformative technology, fundamentally changing photography and numerous other activities by putting a powerful, user-friendly computer in the pockets of over two billion people, thereby beginning the mobile connected era.

Tests confirmed multiple cats, including a seven-month-old named Meereen, died in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, after ingesting antifreeze. The RSPCA is uncertain if the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is appealing for people to safely store and handle chemicals, noting it is a time of year when antifreeze is commonly used.

Despite the Syriza government agreeing to implement harsh new austerity measures, including VAT increases and pension cuts, there are no protests in Greece. This calm may precede the revelation of Prime Minister Tsipras's significant concessions to secure an €86bn bailout, a reversal of his pre-election promises, possibly due to the country's recent economic collapse convincing his party "there is no alternative." Greece is suffering a severe economic squeeze from both fiscal and monetary austerity, which is further impoverishing its people and threatening commerce. For the bailout to lead to a genuine recovery, creditors in Brussels and Berlin must offer substantial debt forgiveness rather than triumphalism.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders for a brief appearance to film the final episodes for the character Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, who will be killed off after her cancer returns. Kemp, a close friend of Windsor's, will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother one last time. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins stated this return will feature the iconic Mitchell brothers facing their mother's death and reuniting with old loves.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was found guilty of murdering Alice Ruggles after stalking and becoming obsessed with her. Her parents, upon being notified by police, immediately knew Dhillon was responsible. Her mother expressed profound guilt for initially downplaying the threat and reassuring her daughter, a mistake she realized after her other daughter, Emma, warned that Dhillon would kill Alice. The parents stated that no one, including Alice, understood the seriousness of the stalking. They established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about stalking dangers and want her remembered for her vibrant personality. Dhillon was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The UK government has unexpectedly delayed its final approval for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant, pausing to "consider carefully" just hours after the French firm EDF, which is financing most of the project, approved the funding. The decision, which surprised EDF and led to the cancellation of a signing ceremony, has raised questions about a potential policy change. The project, which would provide 7% of the UK's electricity, has faced significant criticism over its high cost to consumers, environmental concerns, and financial risks to EDF, leading to resignations from within the company. One-third of the funding is from Chinese investors, a point of concern for some critics who also argue for more investment in renewable energy instead.

A new divorce application form in England and Wales explicitly asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with, which family lawyers warn increases conflict and complexity. While the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name the third party and guidance notes it is not normally necessary, lawyers fear petitioners will fill in the box, making the named individual part of the court case. This can delay proceedings, increase costs, and is frowned upon by judges, with lawyers often advising clients against it despite their desire to involve the new partner.

There is a conflict in Wales between the commercial timber industry and environmental policy. Ministers are prioritizing native broadleaf trees and public access, which the industry group Confor argues comes at the expense of commercial forestry, leading to a loss of 16,000 hectares since 2001. The timber industry is worth over £450m annually to Wales, but it faces bureaucratic hurdles for new planting. While the Welsh government aims for a balanced strategy through its Glastir scheme, Confor states that current planting rates of 90 hectares per year are far below the required 20,000 hectares needed to meet demand and long-term targets.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck in an incident on Bank Street in Coatbridge near Langloan Primary School around 16:40. Emergency crews responded and he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow in serious condition.

Russian Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to British Arctic Convoy veterans, including Able Seaman Charles Lewis, after the UK Foreign Office initially blocked the awards due to rules against foreign medals for events over five years old. The convoys, described by Churchill as the "worst journey in the world," supplied the Soviet Union during WWII, facing U-boats, harsh weather, and significant losses. The Russian Embassy stated the supplies were crucial for defeating Germany on the Eastern Front. Following a campaign, the Foreign Office made an exception, allowing President Putin to present the first medals in 2013.

An HM Inspectorate of Probation report found significant delays and poor enforcement in the administration of unpaid "community payback" work sentences for offenders. Inspectors identified problems such as offenders completing very few hours and facing no consequences for non-attendance, citing one case of only 16 hours completed in 17 months. The report made 15 recommendations for improvement, calling for urgent remedial action to ensure sentences are enforced and delivered effectively. While some high-quality work and positive outcomes for offenders were noted, the chief inspector stated that unpaid work was often viewed merely as a punishment rather than an opportunity for rehabilitation. The Ministry of Justice accepted the report's recommendations and stated it was already taking action to implement them.

A newspaper called a wealthy comedian a "hypocrite" for campaigning for an economic revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home, an accusation he frequently faces. When questioned about his own expensive London property while supporting a housing campaign, he called the reporter "a snide" and walked away. In past explanations, Brand has acknowledged his wealth and past mistakes, accepting the charge of hypocrisy but arguing it is an inevitable personal flaw that does not detract from the need to address systemic economic inequality and ecological disaster, which are the real issues he wants on the agenda.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome through his competitive, often controversial methods, which drew criticism from the scientific community. After this achievement, he focused on creating a synthetic life form, Synthia, a project realized over a decade at his institute. His drive stems from a life-changing experience in the Vietnam War, which instilled a profound sense of urgency. His career breakthroughs include developing faster gene-sequencing techniques, publishing the first complete genome of a free-living organism, and founding the private company Celera Genomics to successfully sequence the human genome. This work provided him with the financial independence to pursue ambitious projects like synthetic biology and global ocean sampling, which he believes could lead to an industrial revolution by creating microbes that produce fuels and capture carbon dioxide.

A survey commissioned by England's School Food Trust found that four out of five children who ate school lunches tried new foods at school that they had not tried at home, with half of parents reporting their children then requested those foods at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The research, prompted by concerns from parents about fussy eaters, indicated that the school environment encourages children to try new foods through peer pressure and a desire to fit in, and that modern school meals offer healthier options and more variety due to strict nutritional guidelines. Approximately 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches.

Álvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker at Euro 2016, joined Juventus from Real Madrid in 2014 with a reported €30m buy-back clause. He scored 27 goals in two seasons for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and played in two consecutive Champions League finals. He began his career at Real Madrid, making his debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the club.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013 but was released in May, leaving him without a team. In his second spell at the club, he made 51 appearances; he had also previously played for Forest, Celtic, Preston North End, and Notts County.

Tesco is making an orderly exit from the US market by selling most of its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a private equity firm run by Ron Burkle. As part of the deal, 4,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while 50 stores will close. Tesco will loan the new company £80m and the disposal will cost it £150m, though part of that is a loan that may be repaid. Tesco retains an option to buy a stake in the business if it becomes profitable.
A British taekwondo athlete, who initially faced racial abuse and considered representing France, overcame these challenges and is now aiming to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

A new inventory of French Alps glaciers, led by Marie Gardent, shows their area has significantly declined from approximately 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s, representing a 26% average loss over 40 years. The retreat, which accelerated after the mid-1980s, is not uniform, with the greatest losses occurring in the southern massifs like Belledonne and Ecrins due to their lower elevation and different climatic conditions compared to the northern areas like Mont Blanc, which receive more precipitation.

The Scottish women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for a major tournament, leading their qualifying group with five wins. A key match against unbeaten Iceland will likely decide who tops the group, with the best group runners-up also qualifying automatically. Player Claire Evans expresses the team's desperation to succeed after recent near-misses and highlights the benefit of having many squad members gaining experience in top foreign leagues, including herself at Bayern Munich. She believes this exposure to different styles of play strengthens the national team.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger from Bath, was arrested in the west of England on allegations of online harassment made by a woman in her 30s from south London, relating to tweets sent over a two-year period. He was released on bail pending further inquiries. Campbell insisted the tweets were not threatening, accused the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation, and stated that the allegations concern only publicly visible tweets from his account, with nothing more sinister alleged.

Peta has called for Skegness to replace its Jolly Fisherman mascot, arguing it represents cruelty to animals and suggesting a new fish logo with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to rebrand the resort as progressive. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, welcomed suggestions but stated he believes the mascot is widely loved and not seen as promoting cruelty, viewing it instead as a happy and friendly symbol for the town. While the matter will go before the council, the mayor expressed strong support for keeping the original Jolly Fisherman, which was commissioned in 1908 for a railway poster and has become synonymous with the resort.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, initially trailing to an early Vasil Lobzhanidze try but then dominating the first half with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg to lead 24-11. Hamish Watson extended the lead after halftime before Lobzhanidze scored a second try from a powerful Georgian scrum. Hogg finished the scoring with a second try from a counter-attack. Scotland's coach Vern Cotter praised the first-half performance and his team's pragmatic management of the game.

Widnes Vikings defeated Castleford Tigers in a close match, taking a 14-6 half-time lead and extending it to 38-12 in the second half. Despite a late surge of three tries in four minutes from Castleford's Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and a hat-trick score from Paddy Flynn (on loan from Widnes), Widnes held on to win. The victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002, was released after a US review board determined he was no longer a significant threat. He was arrested in Pakistan on suspected links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denied, and had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. He was flown home on a Kuwaiti government plane, with his lawyer expressing joy. As part of his release terms, he must spend a year in a Kuwaiti militant rehabilitation center. His release reduces the Guantanamo population to 148; the facility remains open despite President Obama's promises to close it.

The viral song "PPAP" (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) is performed by DJ Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka. The song's creator explained he came up with it by singing while playing music. The video, featuring a catchy beat, silly lyrics, and a simple dance, became a global phenomenon after being uploaded to YouTube and shared on Facebook, where a 9GAG post garnered over 44 million views. While it received a massive international response with numerous tributes and covers, it was not widely covered by Japanese news outlets and received mixed reactions from viewers, ranging from amusement to irritation.

Anzac Day was commemorated in London with a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade of up to 400 people to the Cenotaph, alongside a service at Westminster Abbey. The day honors the first major WWI battle for Australian and New Zealand forces, specifically the Gallipoli landings, a bloody eight-month campaign against the Ottoman Empire. The events, first held in 1916, are significant for expatriates and visitors who honor the sacrifices of their countrymen. The ceremonies included wreath-laying, prayers by schoolchildren, and the national anthems of New Zealand, Australia, and the UK.

David Clarkson, a 30-year-old forward with two Scotland caps, has rejoined St Mirren and is available to make his debut against Alloa. He is match fit from training and playing with the U20s after scoring nine goals for Dundee last season and serving mainly as a substitute this term. With almost 400 senior appearances for clubs including Bristol City, he aims to help eighth-place St Mirren, who are seven points above bottom side Alloa, win games to gain confidence and move up the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. Following productive talks, the new owner's private investment office and the union Unite confirmed that all current agreements, including the existing alternative pension scheme for workers, would be honored. The new ownership plans to restore profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

A fire on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited (run by Asset and Land Group) led to travel disruptions. Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is launching a review to gather evidence on the experiences of older people in residential care, as well as their families and friends, to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. A Sutton Trust report warns that England's apprenticeships are low quality and too short compared to other European countries like Germany. While the Department for Education states reforms are underway to drive up standards, the Association of Colleges agrees with the need for improvement but cautions that some respected Level 2 apprenticeships should be preserved.

British cyclist Sarah Storey won a major event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska, bringing her closer to a potential 17th title. Hereford United was expelled from the Conference Premier for failing to meet multiple extended deadlines to pay its £148,000 debt to football creditors, despite a recent takeover. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has made a takeover bid for the Newport Gwent Dragons, who share Rodney Parade with Newport County AFC. A man who was kidnapped and forced to become a child soldier during Sierra Leone's civil war was later rehabilitated by a preacher. A public fundraising campaign successfully raised the necessary funds to prevent the Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 items from being auctioned off to pay a pension debt inherited from the collapsed Waterford Wedgwood plc. Former England international footballer and reality TV personality Mark Wright is reportedly close to a deal to buy 20% of Isthmian League Premier Division club Billericay Town, which would also see him become a club director. This decision was driven entirely by personal reasons, specifically his family's planned return to Canada in 2018 when his daughters would be completing important school exams. He dismissed any connection to political pressure or criticism of the Bank's Brexit forecasts. Blackpool took an early lead through Jamille Matt, but Colchester United equalized from a corner through Kurtis Guthrie.
