The Healthy Me programme, developed by Action Mental Health, teaches P6 and P7 pupils in Northern Ireland how to cope with change, particularly the stress of transfer tests and the transition to secondary school. The initiative includes interactive workshops that promote emotional wellbeing, teach coping strategies like breathing exercises, and encourage seeking help. It also provides basic training for teachers. A pilot involved five schools, with hopes for a wider rollout. The programme addresses anxiety in children and parents, with educators and inspectors emphasizing the growing need to strengthen youth resilience against modern life's complex challenges.

Developers plan to transform the disused Fawley power station, which closed in 2013, into the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development. The project would repurpose the site's 198-meter-high chimney, making it a major attraction, and includes plans for a petal-shaped glass structure, a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The oil-fired power station, commissioned in 1971 and capable of powering one million homes, was sold to the developers in 2016, who intend to preserve the chimney as a signature feature. An application for outline planning permission is due later this year, with building potentially starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong championships, GB's Chris Latham won bronze in the men's points race, the team's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch. The men's team pursuit lost the bronze to Italy, and the women's team pursuit finished fifth. Olympic gold medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint but is scheduled for further events. Commentators Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's tactical ride and strong finish.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders for a brief reprisal of his role as Grant Mitchell to film the final episodes for the character Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor, who is being killed off after her cancer returned. Kemp agreed to return as a close friend of Windsor's to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother one last time. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins stated the return of the legendary character will bring Grant back to Walford to say goodbye, be reunited with his brother and old loves, and feature powerful scenes as the brothers face their mother's death.

Sadio Mane scored two quick goals as Liverpool defeated second-placed Tottenham at Anfield. Spurs manager Mauricio Pochettino criticized his team's lack of desire and poor start, stating such performances make it difficult to fight for the Premier League title, especially with Chelsea having a chance to extend their lead. Pochettino and pundit Danny Murphy both noted the team's inability to cope with pressure and their uncharacteristically poor defensive performance, with Murphy suggesting a tactical error in not using a back three.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 declared gubernatorial posts, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. The PDP, which also lost the presidential election, was relegated to a regional party, winning only eight governorships mostly in the south-east and failing to secure a national spread of votes. The APC secured most northern states and Lagos but failed to win any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari as it could impact oil revenue. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, though overall more peaceful than in previous years.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19-22, is offering a new augmented reality app. Visitors can use the app to trigger online information, videos, and band interviews from signs and posters on their phones and tablets. This feature is intended to enhance the experience for attendees and also allows people worldwide to interact with the festival, access information, buy tickets, and experience its atmosphere remotely. The app's content will be updated in the lead-up to and during the event.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated, which could remove the Park View Educational Trust from running them. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were also rated inadequate and warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. An anonymous head teacher from one of the "Trojan Horse" schools described a campaign by parents to undermine her authority. Virtual reality (VR) is being used in various unexpected ways beyond entertainment. The "black box" of the Russian Su-24 jet shot down by a Turkish F-16 on 24 November was opened in Moscow, though the head of the Russian investigation stated flight information appeared to be missing. The Scotland women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for a major finals, leading their qualifying group with five wins. A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found there is no "magic bullet" to fix the council tax system, which has had inherent problems since its introduction. A local income tax is perceived as fairer but creates instability for local authorities' income and offers little flexibility. The commission, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, will hold a public consultation before reporting in the autumn, with the government already considering the current system unfair.

Apple has enhanced its iCloud security by making two-factor authentication mandatory for accessing backups, a change prompted by the use of third-party software to steal celebrities' photos. This update blocks tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which previously bypassed the security measure. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed the fix is effective but expressed concerns about the potential for users to lose their recovery key. A security expert argued that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all major tech companies, a sentiment Apple's CEO echoed, stating the company plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable it.

The UKIP party won the May election, spending £2,956,737, which was slightly less than the Conservatives' £2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 but lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, while Labour, which came second, spent £1,027,339. The cost per vote was highest for the Lib Dems at £1.45, followed by the Conservatives at 79p, UKIP at 68p, the Greens at 43p, and Labour at 26p. The total campaign spending for the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087, and all parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election.

Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join National League rivals Torquay United and could play against his former club on 18 February. Separately, Torquay has also signed 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, who was recommended by Micky Adams and has previously played in Ireland; his move is pending international clearance. Manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as young and hungry. The club is currently four points above the relegation zone.

The 10-year-old racehorse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham, having suffered a rare and severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority's acting chief veterinary officer stated such incidents are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Although the horse had a known history of post-race ataxia, which caused him to overheat and wobble, he had shown no symptoms of it on that day, and the report concluded his death was due to a haemorrhage unconnected to his previous condition.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was emotional during the farewell speeches of several MSPs standing down ahead of the election, including Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond. In his valedictory address, Salmond reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and that there is a consensus for the parliament to assume greater governance responsibilities, though he insisted the Scotland Bill did not fulfill all referendum pledges. He also included several light-hearted jokes. McNeil, in his speech, warned that Holyrood must learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure proper accountability and scrutiny. Annabel Goldie also gave a farewell speech, joking about her dealings with the finance secretary.

Emma Watson stars as Belle in Disney's live-action remake of Beauty and the Beast, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as Gaston. The cast also includes Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and a star voicing Mrs. Potts. Directed by Bill Condon, filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios for a US release on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decision on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 fans were unlawfully killed. The evidence files, from investigations into the causes of the disaster and the subsequent police conduct, were referred to the CPS in January. Relatives of the victims will be informed of the decisions at a private meeting, with one family representative expressing the long struggle for accountability and the hope that this marks a journey toward the end of their fight.

Chelmsford Prison has reported numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with a local resident witnessing this four times in two weeks. A former inmate described the jail as "notorious" for being flooded with contraband like mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, also claiming drones were used, though the Ministry of Justice denies drone use at this specific site. The Ministry acknowledged staff work hard to stop contraband but stated more must be done, noting new laws impose up to two-year sentences for smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was seriously injured after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright outside a school in Kempston. Wright, who is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving, admits hitting Blackburn but claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot remember if the traffic light was red. The prosecution stated he failed to stop for a red light while Blackburn, who was wearing appropriate clothing, was crossing the road to escort a child. Wright expressed remorse for his actions, which have left Blackburn in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in April due to a scheduling conflict with her final-year veterinary medicine exams in May. The Scottish middle-distance runner, who recently set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m at the World Championships, expressed disappointment but emphasized the importance of completing her degree. She is targeting the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential competition and believes she has the potential to compete in at least two more future Olympics.

In December 2000, 22-year-old Trevor Deely disappeared after a Christmas party. A new search involving excavations of a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, began and is expected to last weeks. A recent review of his disappearance included enhancing CCTV footage, which shows Deely talking to an unidentified man in black outside his workplace; he was returning to get an umbrella. The same man was later seen following Deely on Haddington Road. Gardaí have not identified this man and have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th, defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in his first Grand Slam since 2014 after multiple wrist surgeries. In the same half of the draw as Andy Murray, he will next face Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios also advanced, coming from behind to beat Dustin Brown in five sets, and will play Feliciano Lopez, who also came from two sets down to win. Other winners included Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations for lodging complaints against CAF after a controversial refereeing decision in their 2015 quarter-final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea; they apologized, resolving the dispute. Separately, Morocco's ban from the 2017 qualifiers, imposed after they refused to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola fears, was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, which also reduced their fine. Both nations subsequently participated in the qualifying draw, with Tunisia placed in Group A and Morocco in Group F.

McLaren, a historically dominant Formula 1 team with 182 grand prix wins and 20 combined championships, is currently in a significant performance slump despite having world champion drivers like Fernando Alonso. This decline began in 2013 with chassis issues and is now attributed to problems with its Honda power-unit, a stark contrast to their legendary and highly successful partnership in the late 1980s. The team's history is a cycle of triumph and decline, and after a disastrous 2013 season, former leader Ron Dennis returned to control. He and the team believe they are arresting the slide with a competitive car and anticipate Honda will improve the engine, insisting it is only a matter of time before they break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again.

Paramedics and police responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven on 6 October 2014, where they found people still present and till receipts showing alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. The bar's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, was charged with two counts and James Thomas with one count of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. A defence solicitor admitted the laws were not strictly adhered to and the premises were improperly run into the morning. The judge, noting O'Neill's appalling record, ordered the bar's closure for three months, fined O'Neill £3,000, and fined Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season by hitting eight to reach a new total, leading the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers. In another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit with a 39-8 run to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, dealing a significant blow to Miami's playoff hopes.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen, a Dutch free-kick specialist, tricked Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic by posing as a competition winner for a dead-ball masterclass. After initially pretending to be unskilled, van Velzen showcased his impressive abilities, surprising and wowing the players. He later revealed it was a prank and enjoyed seeing their reactions.

A study of 676 women with BRCA gene mutations found that those with a BRCA1 mutation who had an oophorectomy (ovary removal) after a breast cancer diagnosis reduced their risk of dying from breast cancer by 62% and from all causes by 65%. The protective effect was immediate and lasted 15 years, with the greatest benefit (a 73% reduction) seen in those who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis. This effect was significant for BRCA1 carriers but not for those with a BRCA2 mutation. The authors suggest oophorectomy should be part of the treatment discussion for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancer.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The train, heading from Charlotte to New York City, hit them as they lingered on the tracks. They were pronounced dead at the scene. None of the 166 passengers were injured, though a man who fell ill during the subsequent delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing. A man who knew the couple suggested they may have been homeless and were struggling to cross the tracks with a grocery cart.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an unpaid undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years with the promise of US citizenship. His work was instrumental in prosecuting major figures like cocaine lord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Now retired due to declining health, the DEA has refused to help him obtain citizenship, leaving him in the US illegally and facing deportation. Toro fears he will be killed if sent back to Colombia, as his final visa has expired and he cannot collect social security benefits without legal status.

The U.S. internet regulator ICANN is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. to determine if its actions with the new '.sucks' domain are illegal, following complaints that it is a predatory scheme to extract high fees from celebrities and companies. Celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have paid to have their names removed from such domains, and major brands like YouTube and Visa have had their names registered. Vox Populi charges trademark holders and celebrities up to $2,499 per year for these domains before offering them to the general public for $10, a practice an advisory panel called a coercive shakedown. If regulators find the actions illegal, ICANN could declare the company in breach of its contract.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a Norfolk pond in 1988. The case was reopened, and the body was exhumed for DNA testing, which led police to the mother. She explained the baby was stillborn, she had concealed the pregnancy, and she had placed the body in the pond. Police ruled out foul play, and the baby was reburied with a named headstone as "Peter" after the local church. The mother was arrested for infanticide, but the charge was dropped; she remains on bail for potential charges of failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered by the High Court to pay compensation to his passenger, Kristopher Hicks, after he was severely injured jumping from the moving vehicle. The judge ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks when he mistakenly believed he would not pay the fare and drove him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. Hicks jumped from the car traveling over 20mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries that require lifelong care. The compensation amount is yet to be finalized but is set to be approximately 50% of the family's request, estimated to be hundreds of thousands of pounds, with an additional £250 awarded for the unlawful imprisonment.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas Wednesday night as multiple storms produced reported twisters, including one near Goddard and others in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. A tornado may have also touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and roof damage. CNN's severe weather expert noted the danger of nighttime tornadoes as storms were expected to continue. More storms were forecast for Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive win and a title shot. Rockhold plans to be the aggressive "bull" to counter Machida's evasive "matador" style, believing he can exploit weaknesses in Machida's game and dominate him on the feet and on the ground. While he respects Machida's skills and longevity, Rockhold is confident in his own abilities and conditioning. Conversely, Machida is also confident, believing his technique and strategy can secure him a victory and that the winner of their fight deserves a title shot.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, an Aerostar light aircraft attempted to land at Aero Acres Residential Airpark without deploying its landing gear, causing it to skid on its belly along the runway. The propellers struck the ground, creating a memorable sound and causing visible damage as the wings bounced. The pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, then applied full throttle to take off again. Despite the damage and a high angle of attack, the engines remained running, and he flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, where he landed safely with his dog onboard. The incident, attributed to pilot error, is under investigation by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Touré's performances this season but has vowed to support the midfielder until the campaign ends. Despite this, the club is reportedly willing to listen to offers for Touré in the summer as part of a squad overhaul. Pellegrini dismissed suggestions that Touré needs a rest, and goalkeeper Joe Hart stated the players have let the manager down and must take responsibility, though Pellegrini retains the dressing room's backing. Separately, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell about a potential move to a big club like Manchester City, citing the examples of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who saw limited playing time after similar transfers.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive living in the UK for over 20 years, will be allowed to remain after his extradition to Italy was halted. His seven-year sentence for Mafia association, issued in absentia in 1999, was extinguished under Italian law because a period more than double the length of his sentence had passed, a fact confirmed by an Italian court. Consequently, the European arrest warrant for his extradition is to be withdrawn. While his conviction remains intact, he can no longer be forced to serve the prison sentence, allowing him to stay in England with his family.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. This race will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One event, and it was after a victory on Mr. Mole in February that he announced his retirement. The seven-runner field also includes Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, recently viewed the crime scene photos after decades of declining to see them. She was horrified by the images of her daughter's disfigured body and expressed a desire for revenge. Marcia's body had been found 33 days after she disappeared, and the case remained unsolved for 33 years until Barrett was convicted in 2009 through DNA evidence and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy believes it is unthinkable that he will not win the Masters to complete the career Grand Slam, a feat achieved by only five other players. He views his 2011 final-round collapse at Augusta as the most important day of his career, as it taught him invaluable lessons that he quickly applied to win his first major at the US Open two months later. McIlroy, who has only one top-10 finish at the Masters, hopes to use the golf course as a sanctuary from the surrounding hype and pressure, focusing on his game to achieve his goal of winning at least one, and potentially multiple, green jackets.

This week's trending stories included four rainbows appearing over New York after heavy rain, a practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes in rural China being targeted in a crackdown, and Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during a UK interview. A new trend, the #KylieJennerChallenge, involved lip plumping by sucking on a jar. Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old with a long criminal history, was jailed for six years after his attempted robbery of a Shildon post office was foiled. Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley—have been charged with the gang rape of a woman in her early 20s at a Canadian naval barracks in Halifax, Nova Scotia, following an alcohol-fueled party on April 10. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, offences carrying sentences of up to 14 years, and are forbidden from contacting the victim and six witnesses. Their next court appearance is scheduled for May 27.

A mother from Las Vegas, Valerie Jackson, was reported to police for child abuse by a stranger who mistook her four-year-old son RJ's rare Netherton's syndrome for burns. RJ is one of only 70 people worldwide with the condition, which makes his skin appear red, scaly, and inflamed. His parents must regularly cover him in creams to manage his painful symptoms. This incident, where armed police surrounded her in a store, is part of a pattern of public ignorance and cruelty the family faces, including being denied entry to play centers and enduring taunts from adults. The condition is a severe, genetic form of ichthyosis with no cure, though symptoms can improve with time.

Transport for London is removing the controversial "Are you beach body ready?" adverts by Protein World from the London Underground network as their paid three-week advertising period has ended. The campaign, featuring a bikini-clad model, had sparked significant backlash, including a petition with over 50,000 signatures, more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) for promoting an unhealthy body image, and acts of vandalism against the posters. TFL stated it noted the public reaction and would consider it for any future similar campaigns. Protein World defended the advert as unphotoshopped and intended to promote fitness, but its aggressive social media responses and the ad's message were criticized as offensive and sexist, leading to a planned protest and even bomb threats against the company.

Rail firms are planning significant fare hikes, including an 87% increase on some First Great Western routes, just days after the general election, despite party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has personally intervened, requesting FGW urgently review its decision to double fares on the London to Cotswolds line that passes through his constituency. Other examples include a 24.5% increase on a Virgin route and a 22% increase on another. Train companies state the changes are to align fares across services and that their overall increases are low, but the hikes have angered constituents and surprised passengers following political promises of price caps.

A 66-year-old former soldier, John Young, was blinded in his left eye after a brick was thrown directly at him when he opened his front door to confront vandals who were pelting his Oldham home with stones. The attack occurred late on April 18, just three weeks after he married his wife, Elaine, as the couple was inside writing thank-you cards for their wedding gifts. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight. Police are investigating but stated there appears to be no motive, suggesting it may have been youths "messing around." The couple, who feel unsafe, plan to move away from the neighborhood.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, who missed the 2014 season due to leg injuries and the death of his father in a road accident, has signed a one-year contract extension until the end of 2016 following his successful comeback, which included a pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. The club's elite performance director praised Poynton's exceptional character and tireless work in his return to fitness and form.

Private jet landing fees vary dramatically across global airports, with the highest fees found in unexpected hubs. The private jet industry is substantial, with millions of flights annually, and its busiest, most expensive periods coincide with major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix.

A video of Katie Gallegos's dog, Cooper the Labrador, eating a McDonald's ice cream cone in one bite has been viewed over seven million times. While his smaller companion, Daisy, eats slowly, Cooper always eats very quickly, so Gallegos ensures Daisy gets her share first. Although some viewers criticized feeding dogs ice cream, Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, defends the occasional weekly treat, stating both dogs are healthy. The dogs also enjoy "pup-uccinos" from Starbucks, which are just whipped cream without coffee.

Kilmarnock interim manager Gary Locke has been appointed to the role on a permanent basis, signing a three-year deal. The former Hearts boss, who initially joined as an assistant, took over in February and has lost only one of his seven games in charge.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son because he wears essential oils from doTERRA, which she applies to help him stay calm and focused. The school claimed the smell was a distraction to other students and staff, sending a letter stating it had created a problem. Despite the threat, the school district later stated it would not suspend Logan, calling it a health issue. Kemp vowed to continue fighting the decision, insisting the natural oils have a positive impact on her son.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, known as the Sandpiper, was completely destroyed by a massive fire that began on Wednesday at 3 PM. The blaze, which spread through 90 condos and caused the building to collapse, was so intense it melted paint off nearby buildings and produced smoke visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews responded but were unable to enter the building. The cause is under investigation, with one claim it may have started near a parked car. The complex is used as a seasonal holiday home from May to November, and a resident and the building manager both expressed shock and reported losing everything.

Despite approaching her 89th birthday, the Queen was seen enjoying a ride on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. A lifelong equestrian who received her first pony at age four, she notably eschews a riding helmet in favor of a silk scarf, reportedly due to her hairstyle. Although a knee injury has reduced her riding in recent years, she remains an enthusiast who breeds Fell ponies at Hampton Court and takes a keen interest in her horses. The Fell pony is an ancient, docile breed from Cumbria, historically used as a pack animal and now popular for riding.

In an effort to identify a woman who died on a Brooklyn street on March 22, the NYPD has released an image of her distinctive tattoo: a heart topped with a rose with the name "Monique" on a ribbon. The woman, who was found unconscious and had no identification, is believed to be between 25 and 45 years old. Police are awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine her cause of death and have asked the public to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers with any information.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 because they could not afford to buy property. The year-and-a-half project, which cost about $25,000, resulted in a wood and steel home on a lot in Nelson where they live nearly self-sufficiently with solar power, a wood-fired stove, gas for hot water, and water from a nearby spring.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class scored approximately 30 points higher on early literacy tests than peers who each had their own device or no iPad at all. The study of 352 students suggests the improvement is due to collaborative learning around the technology, not just collaboration itself, indicating that shared use makes the technology more effective for young students.

A two-legged piglet from Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, born without hind legs, has become an internet sensation. It has mastered walking and balancing on its front trotters, as seen in a viral video where it forages for food and interacts with its four-legged siblings. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," belongs to farmer Ms. Duan and has drawn visits from local villagers. This follows a similar case of a two-legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that also became a popular attraction.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member for Dale Coyne Racing, Todd Phillips, was injured when Francesco Dracone's car spun while exiting its pit box on lap 25, clipping Phillips's leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut at the infield care center and was released. The race, which was affected by rain, saw Dracone not finish and place 23rd.

A husband in Rio de Janeiro, Milton Vieira Severiano, murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, just four days after their wedding. CCTV footage and his confession detail how he brutally smashed her head into concrete 11 times, punched her 10 times, and then shot her in the face five times at point-blank range.
